April 23, 1995: Fiction
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
POLITICALLY CORRECT BEDTIME STORIES, by James Finn Garner.
(Macmillan, $8.95.) Classic tales respun to avoid offending current sensibilities.
BORDER MUSIC, by Robert James Waller. (Warner, $17.95.) A Texas rancher,
trying to erase his Vietnam trauma, takes to the road with an exotic dancer.
OUR GAME, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $24.) Espionage, larceny and murder in
Eastern and Western Europe in the post-cold-war era.
A DOG'S LIFE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The memoirs of Boy, a shaggy
canine in Provence; with drawings by Edward Koren.
MOO, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf, $24.) Intrigues and machinations on the campus of
a Midwestern state university.
THE GLASS LAKE, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $23.95.) The unspoken ties that
bind a woman and her mother in a small Irish town.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$16.95.) A photographer and a farmer's lonely wife in Iowa.
ORIGINAL SIN, by P.D. James. (Knopf, $24.) Adam Dalgliesh probes a case
involving intrigue, malice and murder in a prestigious London publishing house.
SILENT TREATMENT, by Michael Palmer. (Bantam, $21.95.) A physician is the
prime suspect when his estranged wife dies mysteriously in a hospital.
MUTANT MESSAGE DOWN UNDER, by Marlo Morgan. (HarperCollins, $18.) In
Australia's outback, an American woman learns about aboriginal philosophy.
DAISY-HEAD MAYZIE, by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $15.) In words and
pictures, the story of a girl whose head unexpectedly sprouts a daisy.
PHENOMENAL WOMAN, by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $10.) Four poems
celebrating women.
THE FOURTH PROCEDURE, by Stanley Pottinger. (Ballantine, $23.95.) A
Congressman's romances, the abortion wars and medical mayhem played out in
Washington.
THE JUROR, by George Dawes Green. (Warner, $21.95.) A woman's life takes a
fearful turn when she is chosen as a juror for a mob trial.
April 23, 1995
Non-Fiction
THE HOT ZONE, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $23.) The discovery of a
lethal virus, more infectious than H.I.V., and the efforts to keep it from spreading.
THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE, by Philip K. Howard. (Random House, $18.)
How governmental rules and regulations are fettering the lives of all Americans.
BREAKING THE SURFACE, by Greg Louganis with Eric Marcus. (Random
House, $23.) The memoirs of the former Olympic diving champion.
SISTERS, by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth. (Running Press,
$27.50.) The relationships of 36 sets of sisters, reported in words and pictures.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
QUIVERS, by Robin Quivers. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $22.) The memoirs of
Howard Stern's sidekick.
THE DIARY OF A YOUNG GIRL, by Anne Frank. Edited by Otto H. Frank and
Mirjam Pressler. (Doubleday, $25.) The "definitive edition."
COUPLEHOOD, by Paul Reiser. (Bantam, $19.95.) Essays on the ups and downs
of marriage by the television star and stand-up comedian.
AN ANTHROPOLOGIST ON MARS, by Oliver Sacks. (Knopf, $24.) Seven tales
about people who compensated for their neurological afflictions by constructing
worlds of their own.
THE DISCIPLINE OF MARKET LEADERS, by Michael Treacy and Fred
Wiersema. (Addison-Wesley, $25.) A discussion of competitive business
strategies.
THE BOOK OF VIRTUES, by William J. Bennett. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Moral
stories adapted from the Greeks, the Bible, folklore and elsewhere.
FROM BEGINNING TO END, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $20.) The rituals we
practice and the spiritual journeys we take, from childhood to old age.
BEING DIGITAL, by Nicholas Negroponte. (Knopf, $23.) How computers will alter
our lives in the future.
IN SEARCH OF STONES, by M. Scott Peck. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A search for
ancient monuments in Britain becomes an odyssey in quest of faith and reason.
THE WARREN BUFFETT WAY, by Robert G. Hagstrom Jr. (Wiley, $24.95.) An
account of the career of the man said to be the world's most successful investor.
